title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: In our Session there were some influential men: there was Sir James Spittal, who was knighted for being the first Lord Provost under the new constitution under the Reform Bill; there was Commissary Clerk Carphin, grandfather of one of our late elders, James R. Carphin; there was Mr Henderson, of the British Linen Bank, a big, stout man with a tree leg; there was old Mr Noble, a most worthy, godly man, who sometimes came to our house, and liked a glass of port uncommonly, but he never partook of it without first asking a blessing on it and on the household; there was a Mr Menteith, a partner of the Glasgow house of Menteith & Co., famous as Turkey red dyers. After he had entered the business, he was led to be earnest in his piety, and became a student for the ministry; and while attending the Hall in Edinburgh, he acted as an elder with us.

title: A Voyage round Great Britain; with short views of Aberdeen, Balmoral, ... Fécamp, Havre and Paris
author: Hargreaves, Thomas
snippet: The Royal Bank, with an equestrian statue of thc fourth Earl of Hopetoun in front, is a fine building. The adjoining building—the British Linen Bank— has a frontage of isolated Corinthian columns. In the Old Town the most prominent feature is the Castle.
